item.title: Does antioxidant-rich diet make your brain younger? Study explains how - The Times of India
item.description:
Does Antioxidant-Rich Diet Make Your Brain Younger? Study Explains How

Date: October 2023
Source: Medical News Today

Recent research from the University of Kentucky reveals that an antioxidant-rich diet may help lower iron buildup in the brain, thereby reducing the risk of cognitive issues and promoting brain health.

  • A diet high in antioxidants can reduce the risk of numerous diseases.
  • Antioxidants help to scavenge free radicals from body cells.
  • The study involved 72 older adults and measured brain iron levels using advanced MRI techniques.
  • Increased brain iron levels were linked to cognitive decline in specific memory and executive function tasks.
  • Foods high in antioxidants include various fruits, vegetables, nuts, and whole grains.
“Iron is a vital element for brain health, playing a key role in essential cellular functions.” – Valentinos Zachariou, PhD

In conclusion, adopting an antioxidant-rich diet not only promotes physical health but may also lead to improved cognitive functionality and healthier aging.

item.title: Kerala struggles with a surge in mumps cases as infections cross 70,000 this year - The Week
item.description:
Kerala Faces Major Mumps Outbreak with Over 70,000 Cases Reported

Date: 2023
Source: Local Health Department Reports

The state of Kerala is experiencing a significant surge in mumps cases, with over 70,000 reported this year, a dramatic increase from 2,324 cases in 2023. Health officials are concerned about the rising numbers as many individuals seek alternative medical treatments instead of conventional methods.

  • Malappuram and Kannur are severely affected, with 13,643 and 12,800 reported cases, respectively.
  • Schools have closed and mask mandates are in effect to curb the spread.
  • Mumps is a viral illness leading to swollen salivary glands and is highly contagious.
  • Complications of mumps can be severe, especially in unvaccinated individuals.
  • Health officials attribute the outbreak to a lack of vaccinations among children.
“The only way to stop the rise of mumps is to either bring back the MMR vaccine or properly inform people that it is accessible in private hospitals.” - Dr. Aneseya P. Varghese

Despite no reported deaths, health authorities are urging for immediate action to address this urgent public health issue.

item.title: Recap 2024: How pathogens emerged in new territories and forms this year - Down To Earth Magazine
item.description:
Recap 2024: How Pathogens Emerged in New Territories and Forms This Year

Publication Date: 2024
Source: Down To Earth

As threats of new global pandemics loom due to climate change, 2024 has seen the emergence of various pathogens in new regions and forms, raising concerns over potential outbreaks.

  • Experts warn that a new pandemic could arise by 2030 due to zoonotic diseases.
  • The avian influenza strain H5N1 was reported to have killed penguins in the sub-Antarctic for the first time in January 2024.
  • COVID-19 cases saw a global rise, with a new variant, XEC, identified in multiple countries.
  • A mysterious disease resulted in numerous deaths in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
  • A new cholera strain resistant to multiple antibiotics emerged from Yemen, spreading to France.
“More than 80 percent of experts rated expanding or changing range due to climate change as factors that could make outbreaks more frequent or severe.”

The emergence of pathogens and the evolving nature of existing viruses highlight ongoing challenges in global health and the need for proactive measures to anticipate and respond to future outbreaks.

item.title: Polio this week as of 18 December 2024 - ReliefWeb
item.description:
Polio Update: Key Developments as of December 18, 2024

Date: 18 Dec 2024
Source: World Health Organization

This article outlines the latest updates on polio eradication efforts as of December 18, 2024, highlighting significant findings from various global health meetings and reports.

  • The WHO Executive Board will discuss polio eradication strategies in February 2025.
  • Recent recommendations from the SAGE emphasize the importance of concurrent use of IPV and nOPV2 in outbreak response vaccination campaigns.
  • Environmental samples from the UK, Finland, and Germany have indicated the presence of cVDPV2, prompting ongoing investigations by health authorities.
The report provides an update on work towards fully implementing and financing the Polio Eradication Strategy.

The article concludes by stressing the continuous surveillance and monitoring efforts by public health authorities in affected regions, ensuring high vaccination coverage remains a priority.

item.title: Study Reveals Flu Virus Remains Infectious in Refrigerated Raw Milk - Morning Ag Clips -
item.description:
Study Reveals Flu Virus Remains Infectious in Refrigerated Raw Milk

Publication Date: December 12, 2023 | Source: Stanford University via EurekAlert!

This study highlights the risks associated with consuming raw milk, revealing that influenza virus can remain infectious in refrigerated raw milk for up to five days. As concerns about bird flu outbreaks in dairy cattle grow, the findings emphasize the importance of milk pasteurization.

  • Over 14 million Americans consume raw milk annually.
  • The flu virus H1N1 PR8 can remain infectious in raw milk for up to five days.
  • Flu virus RNA can be detected in raw milk for at least 57 days.
  • Pasteurization effectively destroys infectious influenza in milk.
  • Flu viruses infect over 40 million Americans each year, leading to over 50,000 deaths.
  • Recent cases of bird flu in cattle raise concerns about potential transmission through dairy products.
“The persistence of infectious influenza virus in raw milk for days raises concerns about potential transmission pathways.” – Mengyang Zhang

This research sheds light on food safety regarding raw milk consumption and emphasizes the need for improved monitoring systems as avian influenza continues to spread among livestock.

item.title: Colon cancer: Higher biological age linked to increased risk of polyps - Medical News Today
item.description:
Colon cancer: Measuring ‘biological age’ may help predict who's at risk for polyps

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Medical News Today

This article discusses new research indicating that biological age, reflecting an individual’s physiological condition, may be a key predictor of the risk for developing colon polyps, which are precursors to colorectal cancer.

  • Research from the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center suggests faster biological aging correlates with increased polyp risk.
  • For every year of accelerated biological aging, the risk of developing polyps increases by 16%.
  • These findings may lead to earlier screenings for those with accelerated biological ages.
“Biological aging is a measure of your body’s age based on changes in DNA.”
— Shria Kumar, MD, MSCE

Colorectal cancer, particularly among individuals under 50, is rising, emphasizing the need for risk stratification in screenings. Future studies should validate the findings to enhance preventive strategies.

item.title: More than 500 species infected, 300 billion birds dead due to avian flu H5N1: WHO - Down To Earth Magazine
item.description:
Over 500 Species Infected and 300 Billion Birds Dead from H5N1: WHO Warns

Date: 18 Dec 2024

Source: World Health Organization

The Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) H5N1 has infected over 500 species and led to over 300 billion bird deaths globally. The UN has reported that the virus poses significant risks to both wildlife and human livelihoods, particularly in poultry-dependent regions.

  • HPAI H5N1 has spread to 108 countries and has infected numerous wildlife species.
  • The virus poses a threat to food security and livelihoods, especially for poultry farmers.
  • Seventy-six human cases of H5N1 have been reported in 2024, primarily among farm workers.
  • The WHO urges increased surveillance and preventive measures regarding the virus.
“There is no evidence so far that the H5N1 viruses have adapted to spread between people,” said Maria Van Kerkhove, WHO.

This situation highlights the need for a multi-sectoral approach to address avian influenza's spread.

item.title: Russia says it has developed cancer vaccine, will distribute it free of charge - CNBCTV18
item.description:
Russia Develops mRNA Cancer Vaccine to Be Distributed for Free by 2025

Publication Date: N/A Source: CNBC TV18

In a significant medical breakthrough, Russia has reportedly developed an mRNA vaccine against cancer, which will be made available to patients free of cost by 2025.

  • The vaccine is a result of collaborative efforts among several research centres.
  • Pre-clinical trials have shown its capability to suppress tumor growth and prevent metastases.
  • AI technology is being utilized to accelerate the vaccine's development process.
  • The vaccine will help the immune system identify and attack cancer cells.
“We are nearing the creation of cancer vaccines and next-generation immunomodulatory drugs.” - Vladimir Putin

This development holds promise for advancing cancer treatment and is set to impact patients significantly.

item.title: Russia Develops New MRNA Cancer Vaccine, Set For Free Distribution By 2025 - Zee News
item.description:
Russia Develops New MRNA Cancer Vaccine, Set For Free Distribution By 2025

Publication Date: N/A Source: TASS

In a significant advancement, Russia has developed an mRNA-based vaccine targeting cancer, which is slated to be available to patients at no cost by 2025.

Collaborative Effort and Development

Andrey Kaprin, General Director of the Radiology Medical Research Centre, confirmed that the vaccine was developed in collaboration with various research institutions.

Promising Pre-Clinical Results

Pre-clinical trials have shown the vaccine's effectiveness in suppressing tumor growth and preventing metastases. Kaprin stated, “The vaccine’s pre-clinical trials have shown that it effectively suppresses tumor development and potential metastases.”

Presidential Endorsement

Vladimir Putin emphasized the progress in cancer research, hoping for the effective use of these vaccines in individual therapy.

How the mRNA Vaccine Targets Cancer

The mRNA vaccine instructs the body’s cells to produce a protein associated with cancer cells, training the immune system to target and eliminate the disease.

Future Prospects

This mRNA cancer vaccine marks a pivotal moment in medical research, aiming for a 2025 release that could transform cancer treatment.

item.title: Tools You Can Use to Control Winter Asthma, Allergy Symptoms - HealthDay
item.description:
Tools You Can Use to Control Winter Asthma, Allergy Symptoms

Date: December 18, 2024

Source: HealthDay News

Winter is here, and managing asthma symptoms can be challenging due to colder air, increased respiratory infections, and seasonal allergies. Following certain strategies can help control asthma and make winter more enjoyable.

  • Use a scarf or mask to warm the air when outside in cold weather.
  • Maintain good indoor air quality with regular cleaning and air purifiers.
  • Get a flu shot to protect against respiratory infections.
  • Utilize maintenance inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) to keep inflammation under control.
  • Consider SMART (Single Maintenance and Reliever Therapy) for a simplified inhaler approach.
  • Explore biologics for severe asthma management when traditional therapies are ineffective.
“Asthma management in winter can be a challenge, but with the right tools, your symptoms will be better controlled.”

By adopting these practices, individuals with asthma can effectively manage their symptoms and reduce the risk of flare-ups during the winter months.

item.title: Explained: Why cardiac arrest is more frequent in winters; rising BP plays a role - News9 LIVE
item.description:
Why Cardiac Arrests Surge in Winter: The Role of Rising Blood Pressure

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: News9

Rising blood pressure during colder months is identified as a primary driver for heart attacks, particularly among those with pre-existing heart conditions. Health experts stress the importance of awareness and prevention.

  • Patients with heart ailments are advised to move to warmer climates.
  • Cold temperatures can cause blood vessels to constrict, raising blood pressure and increasing heart attack risk.
  • Emotional stress during holiday seasons can heighten the risk of cardiac events.
  • Last year, 35% of cardiac arrests occurred between November and February.
  • Simple lifestyle changes can mitigate risks associated with colder months.
“Winter winds cause the body to lose heat very quickly. If the body temperature drops below 95 degrees, causing hypothermia which in turn damages heart muscle.” - Dr. Narendra Jain

Individuals should remain vigilant, adopt protective measures against cold, and understand warning signs of heart problems to maintain heart health throughout winter.

item.title: Many factors distort blood pressure reading: report - Social News XYZ
item.description:
Many Factors Affect Blood Pressure Readings, Study Reveals

Date: December 18, 2024 | Source: Social News XYZ

A recent report highlights various factors that can distort blood pressure readings, including patient posture and lifestyle choices. Proper measurement techniques are crucial for accurately assessing blood pressure and preventing cardiovascular health issues.

  • Patients often skip essential steps in measuring blood pressure.
  • Factors like sitting posture and recent caffeine intake can skew readings.
  • Guidelines suggest specific positions for accurate measurement.
  • Research indicates that brief daily exercise can positively influence blood pressure.
  • Over 1.28 billion adults globally suffer from hypertension.
"To really make a dent at improving people's cardiovascular health, we need to screen and treat people for hypertension, but we need to do it correctly," - Tammy Brady, Johns Hopkins.

Correct blood pressure measurement techniques are vital for health management and early detection of cardiovascular conditions.

item.description:
Can lifestyle changes reverse diabetes? Insights from TOI Medithon Part 4

Publication Date: [Not available] Source: Times of India

This article discusses the insights gained from the TOI Medithon Part 4 regarding the potential for lifestyle changes to reverse diabetes. It emphasizes the importance of diet and exercise in managing the disease.

  • Focus on lifestyle interventions to combat diabetes.
  • Insights shared by medical experts during the event.
  • Discussion on the role of nutrition in diabetes management.
"Lifestyle changes can significantly impact diabetes management and potentially reverse its effects."

The discussion highlights that sustainable lifestyle changes could be pivotal in diabetes treatment, encouraging individuals to take proactive steps towards healthier living.
